KEY FACTORS TO WATCH TODAY

Global Risk-Off Sentiment  
- Risk-off mood persists for second straight day across global markets.

US Macro Pressures  
- US existing home sales fall most in 4 years despite lower rates.  
- Russia may expand business in US dollars per reports.

US Markets Decline  
- US indices drop on AI spending concerns.  
- Apple cracks more than 5%; US yields dip 7 bps.

Tech & Asia Sell-Off  
- Global tech rout continues for 2nd day.  
- Asian stocks open in red; Bitcoin near $66-67k.

Dollar & Commodities  
- Dollar steady ahead of US CPI inflation data.  
- Brent crude dips 2.5% on sell-off, demand worries & Trump Iran deal remarks.  
- Silver falls almost 10% to near $76/oz on liquidation.  
- Gold sees technical pullback.

FII Flows & Rupee  
- FII shorts unchanged at 78%; cash buying for 4th session.  
- Rupee holds tight range amid mixed cues.

Sector Rotation Ahead  
- Gap down opening expected for IT stocks.  
- Money likely to shift from IT towards BFSI.

Key Takeaway: Risk-off flows favor BFSI rotation over IT pressure in near-term setup.

MOSL ON HAL

Maintains Buy rating with a revised target price of â‚¹5,500 (from â‚¹5,800)

QFY26 revenue/PAT came in line with our estimates

With an estimated order book of ~Rs 2.3 Ik cr to date, we expect this order book to propel manufacturing revenue from the current levels

JPMorgan on IT Sector

Al fears driving a sharp correction

IT firms remain the plumbers of the technology world

Advances such as Claude code's Cowork plugin can meaningfully accelerate complex task

Agentic Al can write a lot more software

Definitely foresee partnerships among Al tool firms and IT Services firms that can create several new areas of work

Al will be another tool to address more work with the same budget like offshore labor, enterprise software, cloud have been in the past

Reverse DCF suggests that stocks bake in 4% terminal growth at current prices with no short term acceleration

Only case with >30% further downside is companies hit 0 terminal growth with no growth hereafter

Both these scenarios appear overly pessimistic to us given the new Al work streams emerging and the likely cyclical recovery

FCF/Div yields scream deep value and are crossing levels prior seen during market dislocation events such as GFC and COVID

Take a barbell approach to buy deep value in large caps

UW, TP Rs 3355

Buy, TP Rs 6000.

CLSA on Muthoot Fin
O-P, TP Rs 4600

Another strong quarter as 3QFY26 NII/PPOP/PAT beat our estimates by 6%-8%. Loan growth of 11% QoQ/51% YoY was c.2ppt above our estimate.

More interestingly is its calculated loan yield expanded QoQ, despite a higher base.

This was driven by continued interest recoveries, which also contributed to the earnings beat.

As a result, its topline grew 13% QoQ. As we highlighted in previous reports, its business model has inherent operating leverage due to the large-fixed costs in the business.

Total Opex, adjusted for the Rs480m one-off labour code impact, was flat QoQ.

Only negative for quarter was 2% sequential decline in tonnage & slowdown in customer acquisitions

Raise EPS estimates by 2-4%.
Recent rally makes the risk-reward ratio unfavourable

JPMorgan on IT Sector

Al fears driving a sharp correction

IT firms remain the plumbers of the technology world

Advances such as Claude code's Cowork plugin can meaningfully accelerate complex task

Agentic Al can write a lot more software

Definitely foresee partnerships among Al tool firms and IT Services firms that can create several new areas of work

Al will be another tool to address more work with the same budget like offshore labor, enterprise software, cloud have been in the past

Reverse DCF suggests that stocks bake in 4% terminal growth at current prices with no short term acceleration

Only case with >30% further downside is companies hit 0 terminal growth with no growth hereafter

Both these scenarios appear overly pessimistic to us given the new Al work streams emerging and the likely cyclical recovery

FCF/Div yields scream deep value and are crossing levels prior seen during market dislocation events such as GFC and COVID

Take a barbell approach to buy deep value in large caps

Overweight on INFOSYS, TCS, Persistent and Sagility

Rajeev Jain, CEO, Bajaj Finance, on Q3 Concall on the Impact of AI â€“

â€œAI listened to 2 Cr calls, converted voice to text, and gave us data. Text-to-data conversion happened for 5.2 lakh customers. As a result, we generated 100,000 new offers for which we did not have information earlier.

â€œThis capability did not exist in Q1 and Q2. It just got deployed. Weâ€™ll be able to listen to 100 million calls next year,â€ said Jain. He added that loan disbursements through AI-powered call centres stood at about Rs 1,600 crore. Thatâ€™s ~ 10% of the Rs 16,545 Cr of disbursals in Q3FY26

Data converting -- data from those calls led to another INR 325 crores of volumes. So, this is just our first attempt.

Over the next six months, Bajaj Finance plans to invest heavily in its agents. The company expects to have more than 800 autonomous agents across sales, operations, HR, IT, risk, and DMS in the next fiscal.
Similarly, in terms of 100% of videos are now generated by us using AI, 100% of banners are generated using AI, 2.7 lakh videos were generated, and 1.2 lakh banners were generated. At the customer engagement level, we have 11 AI text BOTs that are live that engage with the customer. So rather than sending dumb SMSs for 11 products now, we have an AI text BOT, which allows you to engage, interact, and respond to your queries.

The company has 26 products. All 26 will be live between April and May'26. So, there will be no communication that we'll be sending, which will not have a -- whether service or sales, which will not have a conversational BOT embedded in it.

At the branch and point of sale, existing customers face match that we're doing, we did 46 million face matches to ensure this is the same customer, if it's an ETB customer who had actually principally come in, giving us much better control over identity.

Customer onboarding in terms of document -- ensuring that auto-fill of the document happens, whether it's a PAN card or an Aadhaar. There are 43 such documents that the company has now mapped, which an image extracts with a 95% - 96% accuracy and populate data in our platforms, delivering significant productivity for our employees.

Auto quality check of documents is now 41%. As we sharpen the model, it will take us to between 85% and 90% over a period of the next 15-odd months

On technology development, we are clearly seeing between 25% - 45% efficiencies emerging in terms of the development process, depending on whether it's a legacy platform, then the benefit is much lower, or rather, I would say, none. But if it's a digital infrastructure, then the efficiencies can be as high as 45% - 47%. So significant work is being done.

Voice AI Revolution

Identity & Onboarding AI

Development Efficiency

**MOTILAL OSWAL ON INDO STAR CAPITAL | TP â‚¹270 | Buy**

**Rating & Target**  
- Motilal Oswal maintains **Buy** on Indo Star Capital with a **target price of â‚¹270**.  

**Q3 Performance**  
- **AUM declined ~2% YoY**, reflecting a conservative stance as the company operated under **tighter underwriting norms focused on asset quality**.  
- **Vehicle finance (VF) disbursements grew ~21% QoQ**, indicating underlying growth momentum in the core retailâ€‘vehicle segment.  

**Growth & Margin Outlook**  
- Motilal projects **~17% CAGR in AUM** and **~31% CAGR in PPOP over FY26â€“FY28**.  
- Earningâ€‘power leveraged by **NIM expansion to 9.9% in FY26E** and **11.4% in FY27E**, driven by betterâ€‘yield assets and controlled costs.  

**Key Takeaway**  
Despite a relatively weak 3QFY26 with slower AUM growth due to tight underwriting, Motilal sees Indo Star Capital poised for strong PPOP and AUM CAGR over the next two years, underpinned by improving NIM and disciplined balanceâ€‘sheet management, justifying the Buy view at â‚¹270.

- Revenue growth of **13.5%**, underpinned by volume and mix.  
- Projects **~12% CAGR in EBITDA from FY26â€“FY28**, driven by rampâ€‘up in durables and aerospace verticals.  

**Morgan Stanley â€“ Overweight | TP â‚¹144**

- Aerospace business saw **+41% YoY growth**, a key earnings driver.  
- Net debt/EBITDA at **1.1x** and capex execution remain on track.  

**Nomura â€“ Buy | TP â‚¹140**

- Forecasts **21% revenue CAGR in FY27** and **11% growth in FY28**, supported by **PVâ€‘cycle recovery and new greenfield ramps**.  

**Street Impact**

- Core view: **growth levers in autos, EV components and aerospace remain intact**, supporting earningsâ€‘backed rerating over the medium term.

**CLSA ON GOLD FINANCIERS | Muthoot Outperform / Manappuram Hold**

**Muthoot Finance â€“ Outperform | TP â‚¹4,500**  
- CLSA upgrades its **Muthoot Finance target to â‚¹4,500**, maintaining **Outperform**.  
- Three key PATâ€‘growth drivers highlighted:  
  - **Rising gold prices**, boosting collateral value and ticket size.  
  - **Scope to increase LTV ratios meaningfully**, supporting loanâ€‘book growth with manageable risk.  
  - **Operating leverage** as the asset base scales.  
- **FY26â€“28CL PAT estimates for Muthoot upgraded by 4â€“9%**, mainly due to higher projected loan growth.  

**Manappuram Finance â€“ Hold | TP â‚¹305**  
- CLSA keeps **Manappuram at Hold** with a **target price of â‚¹305**.  
- Structural positives are recognised, but valuations and regulatoryâ€‘norm readjustments keep upside capped versus Muthoot.  

**Key Takeaway**  
CLSA sees Muthoot positioned for strong PAT pulled by gold, higher LTV and operating leverage, justifying a higher â‚¹4,500 target; Manappuram, while fundamentally sound, is viewed as a tactical Hold with limited rerating scope in near term.

**NOMURA ON SANSERA | TP â‚¹2,342 | Buy**

**Rating & Target**  
- Nomura maintains **Buy** on Sansera.  
- Target price set at **â‚¹2,342**.  

**3Q Performance**  
- Q3 results came **ahead of estimates**, with the business **firing across all cylinders**.  
- **Nonâ€‘auto revenue gaining strong traction**, particularly in **Automotive & Defence Systems (ADS)**, indicating diversification success.  
- **Exports are also recovering well**, adding to volume and mix benefits.  

**Valuation & Growth**  
- Stock trades at **~26x FY28 forward EPS**, which Nomura views as **attractive**.

reports.text:
KIMS is one of the only 7 companies (US$3bn+ Mcap) in India to offer ~30%+  topline CAGR over FY25-28E along with a FY28 RoE of ~25%

According to GS

**FADA January 2026 Vehicle Retail Sales Data â€“ Telegram Ready**

**Headline**  
- **Total auto retail sales at 27.22 lakh units (+17.61% YoY)**, confirming strong start to the calendar year across most segments.

**Segmentâ€‘wise breakdown**  
- **2W**: 18.53 lakh units (+20.82% YoY)  
- **PV**: 5.13 lakh units (+7.22% YoY)  
- **3W**: 1.27 lakh units (+18.80% YoY)  
- **CV**: 1.07 lakh units (+15.07% YoY)  
- **Tractors**: 1.15 lakh units (+22.89% YoY)  
- **Construction Equipment**: 6,834 units (â€‘21.09% YoY)  

**Rural strength drivers**  
- Supported by **good harvest, wedding season, MSP hikes**, and **festivals like Pongal/Makar Sankranti**.  
- Rural demand remains a key growth engine for 2W, tractors, and entry PVs.

**Urban demand trends**  
- **Normalisation postâ€‘festive buying**, with a **clear shift toward higherâ€‘value models** in PVs and premium 2Ws.  
- Indicates sustained upgrade cycle in urban/semiâ€‘urban markets.

**Key operating metrics**  
- **Inventory levels lean and healthy at 32â€“34 days**, reducing risk of forced discounts or pricing pressure.  
- **Digitalisation** is accelerating **enquiryâ€‘toâ€‘conversion cycles**, improving dealer efficiency.

**Nearâ€‘term outlook**  
- **Sustained demand visibility** across segments, tempered by **cautious optimism** and **segmentâ€‘specific recalibration** (e.g., CE facing highâ€‘base pressure).  
- Focus on resolving **supply constraints** and **competitive pressures** to sustain retail momentum.  
- **Overall sentiment remains Positive**.

**One key takeaway**  
January FADA data validates a **multiâ€‘segment, multiâ€‘quarter upcycle** in auto retail, underpinned by rural resilience and urban upgrades, with lean inventories and positive outlook pointing to continued volume and earnings traction.

**MOTILAL OSWAL ON GSK PHARMA â€“ NEUTRAL, TP â‚¹2,700**

**Rating & target**  
- Maintain **Neutral** on GSK Pharma with a **target price of â‚¹2,700**.  
- View reflects decent operating momentum but already reasonable valuations.

**Performance highlights**  
- Recent quarter reported **inâ€‘line revenue** with the **highest quarterly EBITDA margin**, signalling mix and operatingâ€‘leverage benefits.  
- **Oncology products in the specialty segment remain strong**, supported by **RUBYâ€‘1 portfolio** and the **scaleâ€‘up of Zejula/Jemperli**.

**Earnings revisions**  
- Motilal Oswal **raises estimates by 5% for FY26, 2% for FY27, and 2% for FY28**, reflecting sustained specialtyâ€‘product growth and margin stability.  
- Broker expects an **earnings CAGR of ~13% over FY26â€“FY28**.

**Key takeaway**  
GSK Pharma is executing well in oncology and specialty medicines with healthy margins, but the Neutral stance suggests that much of the earningsâ€‘growth story is already priced in at current levels.

**MOTILAL OSWAL ON BOSCH â€“ NEUTRAL, TP â‚¹35,504**

**Rating & target**  
- Maintain **Neutral** on Bosch, revising target to **â‚¹35,504** from â‚¹36,103.  
- View reflects a mix of nearâ€‘term misses and better mediumâ€‘term structuring.

**Earnings & segment performance**  
- Recent **earnings missed estimates**, driven by **weakerâ€‘thanâ€‘expected performance in the nonâ€‘auto segment**.  
- **Margins came in lower**, pressuring profitability versus consensus.

**Auto segment recovering**  
- **Autoâ€‘segment demand has picked up after GST 2.0 reforms** and is tailwinds for autoâ€‘OEM suppliers.  
- Players like Bosch are **wellâ€‘positioned to benefit** from improved cycle and higher replacementâ€‘parts activity.

**Mediumâ€‘term growth outlook**  
- Motilal Oswal expects Bosch to post a **10% CAGR in revenue**, **12% CAGR in EBITDA**, and **14% CAGR in PAT over FY25â€“FY28E**.  
- The upgrades factor in operatingâ€‘leverage benefit once volumes and mix stabilise.

**Key takeaway**  
Nearâ€‘term pressure from nonâ€‘auto is balanced by autoâ€‘cycle recovery and solid mediumâ€‘term earnings growth; Neutral rating is appropriate until margin and segmentâ€‘mix risks clear further.

**MOTILAL OSWAL ON NSE â€“ Growth & Diversification Play**

**Strong volume momentum**  
- NSE seeing a **strong volume uptick**, underpinning transactionâ€‘driven revenue.  
- **Transaction charges** dominate the revenue mix and grew **9% QoQ**.

**Revenue diversification progress**  
- **Listing services revenue up 26% QoQ**, reflecting the exchangeâ€™s push beyond pure trading income.  
- Mix is gradually broadening into other feeâ€‘based and listingâ€‘related streams.

**Earnings outlook**  
- Motilal Oswal raises **earnings estimates** to incorporate the current **strong volume run rate**.  
- Expects **15% CAGR in revenue**, **14% CAGR in EBITDA**, and **15% CAGR in reported PAT over FY26â€“FY28**.

**Key takeaway**  
NSE looks set for a multiâ€‘year earnings compounding phase powered by strong volumes and incremental diversification, making it a coreâ€‘hold in the financialâ€‘infrastructure space as long as trading activity sustains.

**Citi Turns Cautious on India IT Services**

**Stance**  
- Citi adopts a **Cautious** stance on Indiaâ€™s ITâ€‘services sector  
- Expectations are for **moderate rerating only after clear visibility on AI and demand**  

**Why the caution?**  
- Recent **price correction driven by AI worries** and concerns over longâ€‘term terminal growth  
- **Nearâ€‘term outlook remains deflationary** for volumes and pricing  
- **Mediumâ€‘term outcomes around AI adoption and deal growth are still uncertain**  

**Margins still under pressure**  
- Company margins continue to face headwinds despite some **support from currency moves**  
- Revenue growth in India is expected to stay **lowâ€‘singleâ€‘digit in FY26**  

**Largeâ€‘cap preferences**  
- Within largeâ€‘cap IT, Citi favours **Infosys and HCL Tech** over some peers  
- View is based on **client mix, execution, and relative positioning** in a tough cycle  

**Key takeaway**  
Nearâ€‘term upside in India IT looks limited; focus should be on stockâ€‘selection and waiting for clearer signs of demand and margin stabilisation before chasing broadâ€‘sector bets.

**MOTILAL OSWAL ON BSE â€“ NEUTRAL, TP â‚¹3,350**  

**Rating & Target**  
- Motilal Oswal maintains a **Neutral** rating on BSE with a **target price of â‚¹3,350**, up from the earlier â‚¹2,950.  
- The higher target reflects stronger nearâ€‘term operating momentum and an uplift in earnings estimates.  

**Revenue & F&O Drivers**  
- **F&O momentum** is the key growth driver, with **F&O volumes doubling YoY**, directly boosting **transactionâ€‘based revenue and charges**.  
- This has resulted in **strong topâ€‘line growth**, especially in the exchangeâ€™s core listings and trading businesses.  

**Strategic Investments**  
- BSE is making **continued investments in technology, data infrastructure, and product diversification** (including new derivatives and indices), which are expected to:  
  - **Strengthen its competitive positioning** versus NSE, and  
  - Enhance **longâ€‘term earnings visibility and operating leverage**.  

**Earnings Estimates**  
- Motilal Oswal has **raised its earnings estimates** for BSE by:  
  - **+5% for FY26**,  
  - **+15% for FY27**, and  
  - **+13% for FY28**.  
- The upward revision incorporates robust F&O growth, improved operational efficiency, and benefits from product and technology expansion.  

**Key Takeaway:**  
The Neutral view reflects that while BSE is executing well on volume and technology, the stock is already embedded with much of this growth; upside is now more dependent on sustained F&O traction and margin expansion, with limited nearâ€‘term surprise potential.

**ELARA ON STAR CEMENT â€“ BUY, TP â‚¹302**  

**Rating & Target**  
- Elara maintains **Buy** on Star Cement with a **target price of â‚¹302**, valuing the stock at **12x Decâ€‘27E EV/EBITDA** on a rolledâ€‘forward basis.  

**Margins & Profitability**  
- Company continues to show **margin leadership**, with **EBITDA/tonne at â‚¹1,562**, the **fourth consecutive quarter of sectorâ€‘leading margins**.  
- **Q3 FY26 EBITDA up ~94% YoY and ~6% QoQ**, driven by **strong volume growth and lower power & fuel costs**.  

**Volumes & Growth Trajectory**  
- **Volumes up ~21% YoY**, among the **highest growth rates** across Elaraâ€™s cement coverage.  
- Onâ€‘going **capacity rampâ€‘up** and recent **expansion announcements** are expected to support **mediumâ€‘term volume growth**.  

**Earnings Estimates**  
- Brokerage **raises FY26E EBITDA by ~5%**, while keeping **FY27â€“28 estimates unchanged**, indicating confidence in nearâ€‘term operating strength.  

**Key Risks Highlighted**  
- Main risks flagged include **weak demand recovery**, **cementâ€‘price pressure**, and a **potential spike in fuel costs**, which could erode the attractive margin profile.  

**Key Takeaway:**  
Star Cement trades as a highâ€‘quality, marginâ€‘leader story with strong volumes and capexâ€‘backed growth; Buy stance assumes disciplined pricing and controlled fuelâ€‘cost spikes, making it a coreâ€hold with watchlists on demand and inputâ€‘cost trends.

**INVESTEC ON STAR CEMENT â€“ SELL, TP CUT TO â‚¹179**  

**View & Target**  
- Investec downgrades Star Cement to **Sell** with a **target of â‚¹179**.  
- The recent **earnings beat was largely driven by pricing**, not a fundamental volume or mix turnaround.  

**Guidance & Expansion Plans**  
- Management has **downgraded FY26 volume guidance**, signalling softer demand visibility.  
- Company is planning **greenfield expansion into the North**, but Investec notes that **return math does not cover the cost of capital** for this move.

**M M Forgings Ltd â€“ Earnings Inflection as CV Cycle Turns Favorable; Initiate BUY**

**Investment Thesis**  
- Equirus initiates **BUY** on MM Forgings with **Marâ€™27 target of â‚¹596** (CMP ~â‚¹449 â†’ 33% upside)  
- View: earlyâ€‘cycle upturn in commercial vehicles (CVs) from FY27â€“FY28 onwards, with strong margin and earnings leverage  
- Expect **Revenue / EBITDA / PAT CAGR of 13% / 21% / 36% over FY26â€“FY28E**, with EBITDA margin rising from 17.3% in 1HFY26 to ~19.8% in FY28E  

**Macro & Sector Backdrop**  
- Indian automotive contributes ~7.1% to GDP; Indian forging market ~US$5.2bn in 2024, forecast to rise to ~US$10.2bn by 2033 at ~7.8% CAGR  
- Global forging market ~$80â€“90bn, growing at 5â€“6% CAGR, driven by automotive, industrial, aerospace, and energy plus demand for lightweight and highâ€‘strength components  
- Indian CV industry had a weak FY25 (sales down 1.2%), but looks poised for a multiâ€‘year upcycle; MMFG tilted toward MHCV and replacementâ€‘led domestic demand makes it a key beneficiary  

**Company & Business Model**  
- Founded in 1946; fully integrated forging and precisionâ€‘components manufacturer with ~145k TPA installed capacity  
- Supplies heavy components such as crankshafts, front axle beams, and knuckles to OEMs in CV, PV, tractor, and offâ€‘highway segments  
- Domestic revenue carries ~80% of FY25 revenue (PV ~12%, agriculture & offâ€‘highway ~8%); exports ~38%  

**Recent Performance & Earnings Inflection**  
- FY25 revenue down ~3% YoY to ~â‚¹1,477 crore, weighed by soft domestic CV demand, US Class 8 slowdown, and muted steel passâ€‘through  
- EBITDA margin expanded 103 bps YoY to 19.9% on higher machining mix (~58%) and cost efficiencies  
- 1HFY26 revenue down 4.1% YoY to ~â‚¹727 crore; EBITDA margin moderated to 17.3% as peak capex cycled through  
- Net debt ~â‚¹8.3 billion; with capex largely behind the company, cash flow and deleveraging are expected to improve from FY27  

**Growth Engines & Strategic Shifts**  
- Shift toward domestic MHCV and higherâ€‘value machined components: domestic revenue CAGR ~20% over FY18â€“FY25 versus ~7% for exports  
- Machining mix rose from ~20% in FY16 to ~58% in FY25, targeted to reach 65â€“70%, with new orders skewed 90â€“95% to machined parts  
- Large capex cycle expanded capacity from ~65k TPA to ~145k TPA; utilization still only ~48% in FY25, leaving strong headroom for volume growth  
- Worldâ€™s largest 16,500â€‘ton forging press (Indiaâ€™s first) expected to start contributing from FY27, with peak revenue contribution of ~â‚¹300 crore annually and order book of ~â‚¹300 crore (largely executable from FY27), implying ~â‚¹500â€“700 crore incremental revenue potential over 2â€“3 years  

**Profitability & Valuation**  
- FY25 EBITDA ~â‚¹294 crore on ~â‚¹1,477 crore sales; recurring PAT ~â‚¹136 crore, EPS ~â‚¹28.2  
- Equirus forecasts FY26â€“FY28E EBITDA rising from ~â‚¹259 crore in FY26E to ~â‚¹378 crore in FY28E, with EBITDA margin improving to ~19.8%  
- On the earnings ramp, **FY26E / FY27E forward P/E multiple is around 23.8x / 16.7x**, viewed as attractive given the cyclical upturn and margin expansion  

**Peer & Risk Perspective**  
- Equirus compares MMFG favorably with Bharat Forge, Ramkrishna Forgings, and Happy Forgings, emphasizing **earnings inflection, margin expansion, and deleveraging potential**  
- Key risks: high CVâ€‘revenue concentration (~80% of FY25), dependence on a limited set of global customers (topâ€‘10 ~58% of FY24 revenue), weaker US Class 8 demand, and lingering export headwinds; highly cyclical link to CV sales plus limited nonâ€‘auto diversification  

**Key Takeaway:**  
MM Forgings is entering a favorable CVâ€‘cycleâ€‘driven earnings inflection, with strong capacity headroom, a rising proportion of higherâ€‘margin machined components, and a meaningful deleveraging story ahead, giving investors a leveraged play on Indiaâ€™s industrial and heavyâ€‘vehicle recovery.

**SBI Q3FY26: MS Equal-weight at Rs 1,025 TP**

**Rating Stance**  
- Strong quarter: core PPoP +4% beat MS ests, PAT +28% beat  
- Stays **Equal-weight** - valuation (1.3x FY27e core PB) prices in gains  
- FY26 EPS +8%; FY27/28 unchanged (near-term upgrade only)  

**Profitability Drivers**  
- PAT **Rs 210 bn** (+24% YoY/+4% QoQ, 28% above ests)  
- Core PPoP +4% beat; IT refund 2.7% PBT, dividends 8% PBT  
- Adjusted NII +4% QoQ in-line; core PPoP +10% QoQ/+12% YoY  
- 3Q RoA 1.19%, RoE 15.9%; FY26-28 RoA 1.0-0.9%, RoE to 12.6%  

**Loan & Deposit Mix**  
- Domestic advances +15% YoY/+7% QoQ (vs 12% YoY 2Q)  
  - SME: +21% YoY/+11% QoQ (13% mix)  
  - Retail: +15% YoY/+4% QoQ (36% mix; housing +15%, xpress +6%)  
  - Agri: +17% YoY/+7% QoQ (8% mix)  
- Intl +13% YoY/+2% QoQ; total book +15% YoY/+6% QoQ  
- Deposits +9% YoY/+2% QoQ: CA -4% QoQ/+10% YoY, SA +2%/+9%, term +3%/+9%  
- CASA ~38%; domestic LDR 73% (vs 70% 2Q), overall 81%  

**Margins & Fee Growth**  
- NIM 2.99% (flat QoQ ex-IT refund; vs 2.97% 2Q)  
- FY26 exit ~3%, FY26-28 avg 3.0% (vs FY25 3.1%)  
- Fees +16% YoY (+1% vs ests); cross-sell +21% YoY/+24% QoQ  
- Non-interest income Rs 184 bn (+66% YoY/-8% QoQ)  

**Costs & Asset Quality**  
- Opex Rs 307 bn (+6% YoY/-1% QoQ, -2% vs ests)  
  - Staff flat YoY/-4% QoQ; other opex +14% YoY/+2% QoQ  
- CIR **48.3%** (vs 55.1% 3QFY25, 49.3% 2Q)  
- Slippages Rs 49-50 bn (0.5% ann.); recoveries Rs 24 bn, write-offs Rs 51 bn  
- GNPA Rs 736 bn (1.57%, -3.4% QoQ/-12.7% YoY); NNPA 0.4%; coverage 76%  
- Credit cost 40 bps (net 17 bps); SMA-1/2 at 8 bps  
- CET1 12.6% (+10 bps QoQ); CAR 14.8% FY25 â†’ 13.5% FY28; LCR 138%  

**Subsidiaries & DuPont**  
- SBI Cards Rs 5.56 bn (+45% YoY/+25% QoQ)  
- SBI Funds Rs 8.26 bn (+52% YoY/+11% QoQ)  
- SBI Life Rs 5.77 bn (+5% YoY/+17% QoQ)  
- Cons PAT Rs 213 bn (+13% YoY/+1% QoQ)  
- Subs value Rs 229/share (post 20% holdco discount from Rs 286)  
- DuPont: revenue/assets 3.4%, core PPoP/assets 1.2-1.4%, provisions 0.2-0.3%  

**Valuation & Scenarios**  
- CMP Rs 1,066 (PE 12.7-11.9x, PB 1.8-1.4x; core PB 1.3x FY27)  
- Core Rs 837 + subs Rs 229 = CMP  
- **Base PT Rs 1,025** (1.2x core PB): 13-14% growth, 3.0% NIM, 50 bps credit  
- Bull Rs 1,635 (1.8x): faster growth/margins; Bear Rs 605 (0.7x): slowdown/NPLs  
- Concerns: deposit competition, CASA drift, NIM/credit normalization  

**Key Takeaway:**  
Excellent ops fully priced in; MS favors peers for superior risk-reward as NIM/credit costs mean-revert.

**SBI Q3FY26: Strong Beat, Neutral Call**

**Profitability Surge**  
PAT hit **Rs 210 bn**, up 4% QoQ/25% YoY, beating expectations via stable NIM, robust non-interest income, controlled opex, and benign credit cost (~40 bps).  
RoA at **1.2%** tops 1% target; FY26E RoE pegged at **15.2%**.  
PPOP jumped **40% YoY** with 1.9% PPOP RoA.

**Growth Momentum**  
Loans accelerated to **6.1% QoQ/15.6% YoY**; FY26 guidance raised to **13-15% YoY**.  
Broad-based: SME +10.8% QoQ, corporate +7.6% QoQ, retail +4.4% QoQ.  
Deposits softer at **2% QoQ/9% YoY** (LDR ~81%), but pipeline strong.

**Stable Margins**  
NIM steady at **2.99%** (table: 2.93%) via higher LDR, lower funding costs.  
4Q NIM expected >**3%**, targeting ~**3%** through-cycle.

**Fee & Cost Control**  
Non-interest income soared **66% YoY/20% QoQ** to Rs 184 bn (fees +15.6% YoY).  
Opex at Rs 307 bn, down **1% QoQ**; CIR improved to **48.3%** (FY27 target <50%).

**Asset Quality Solid**  
GNPA **1.7%**, NNPA **0.4%** (both improved QoQ/YoY); slippages mid-40 bps.  
Gross NPAs down **3.4% QoQ**; PCR mid-70s.

**Valuation View**  
CET1 at **11%** adequate for 15% RoE.  
Target raised to **Rs 1,100** (from 1,050) at 1.2x FY27 PB/9x PE; **Neutral** rating on balanced risk-reward.

**Key Takeaway:**  
Operational strength intact, but valuation limits upside versus mid-cap PSBs.

https://t.me/addlist/7yWSFQA7ITU2ODc1

**RGL: D2C Pivot Powers Revival**  

**Sector Tailwinds**  
Gems & Jewellery faced sluggish demand from tariff overhang, but US-India trade improvement signals revival. RGL shines with strong US presence and rising D2C focus.  

**Strategic Shift**  
- Transitioning from B2B exporter to brand-led B2C platform.  
- Owned brands hit â‚¹18.7bn (FY24), targeting 36% CAGR to ~â‚¹47.8bn by FY27.  
- D2C mix rising from 10% to 23%, boosting revenue quality and margins.  

**Premium Brands**  
- Jean Dousset (ethical luxury LGD) commands ~90% pricing premium.  
- NY boutique delivers ~25% RoI; store count to hit 5 by Junâ€™26.  

**Growth Projections**  
- EBITDA at 24% CAGR.  
- D2C margins expanding 5% to 18%; licensed brands at ~18%.  

**Investor Angle**  
Asset-light, high-margin D2C strategy ensures earnings visibility and re-rating. Valued at 8x FY27E earnings with significant upside as branded mix scales.  

**Key Takeaway:**  
RGLâ€™s branded D2C acceleration positions it for strong re-rating amid sector recovery.

- With no further rate cuts, **NIM recovery expected in FY27**.  

**Key Takeaway:**  
Cleaned-up overhang + FY27 NIM recovery setup keeps **Buy** thesis intact.

**Morgan Stanley: PFC-REC Merger View**

**Borrowing Strength**  
- Both enjoy **diversified profiles**; bank exposure limits possible post-merger.  

**Asset Side**  
- **Limited limitations** expected.  

**Ownership Impact**  
- PFC acquiring REC stake drops govt to **42%**.  
- Likely requires **additional govt infusion** for 50%+ control.  

**Synergies**  
- **Limited cost savings**; some revenue potential.  
- Merger structure **unclear**.  

**Key Takeaway:**  
PFC-REC merger offers revenue synergies but needs govt capital top-up amid bank limits.

**ICICI Sec: India-US Deal Radar**

**Key Wins**  
- Agri/dairy **largely excluded** â€” protection intact.  
- Benefits: **Auto components, aircraft parts, generic pharma**.  
- India ramps US high-end products/energy buys.  

**Tariff Relief**  
- **~50%** India-US exports now **zero tariff**.  
- Covers: **Electronics, pharma, gems/diamonds, aircraft/auto parts, chemicals, agri/food**.  
- Notification via executive order soon.  

**Market Call**  
- CY26E **Nifty50 target 29,000** maintained.  

**Key Takeaway:**  
Deal slashes tariffs on **50% exports** â€” auto/aero/pharma shine while agri shielded.

Nomura On India US Trade Deal

BROKERAGE RADAR

Welcome clarification of the fine-print of the trade deal agreed upon between India and the US

It should quell some of the uncertainty building in markets after the initial cheer of the deal

India's ability to stick to its red lines, particularly on agriculture, means that political opposition to the deal should be muted

Additional information regarding the removal of tariffs on gems & diamonds, aircraft parts and carve-outs of the sectors impacted by the Section 232 tariffs is a positive development for India

Purchase commitment of USD500bn over five years - whether these commitments are met or delayed remains to be seen

Nevertheless, this remains an important metric to track going forward

Bernstein On India US Trade Deal

BROKERAGE RADAR

The US and India treaty appears fairly constructive and it looks like a positive setup

Looks like a mature handling of the trade agreement from the US and India-which has been missing for a year now

Market euphoria was fading away leading to skepticism over how beneficial the deal is to India

This announcement clears up much of that, and sets the markets for a relief

Believe the fine print released so far is broadly positive for markets, especially for auto components and shields pharma from a potential negative

The economic costs of switching to far-off crude will also be outweighed by tariff benefits

Various other products such as textiles, gems and jewelry, organic chemicals, etc., where India has high exports to the US, will now face 18% duty vs 50% earlier; So this is a positive

However, there are not many direct and large stocks to invest in to play this benefit

Remain Neutral on India with a 28,100 Nifty target

Near-term short-term rally argument is for Nifty moving until 26,500, closer to where we started the year

reports.text:
**The Copper Crunch: Why AI and Energy are Testing Geological Limits**

â€‹The world is facing a potential copper shortage as the massive expansion of **AI data centres** and global **power demand** collide with the physical limits of mining. With prices hitting record highs of **$12,000 a tonne**, the "red metal" has become a strategic bottleneck for the future economy.

**â€‹Why the Supply is Tightening:**

â€‹**AI Data Centre Proliferation:** The rapid growth of AI infrastructure is a primary driver of the massive increase in copper demand.

â€‹**Renewable Energy Intensity:** Generating just **1 gigawatt (GW)** of wind power requires roughly **2,866 tonnes of copper**.

â€‹**Operational Challenges:** To get that much copper from mines with a 0.6% yield, miners must process between **167â€“200 tonnes of ore** for every single tonne of metal produced.

â€‹**Geopolitical Chokepoints:** Supplies are becoming increasingly volatile due to mine outages in Indonesia, Congo, and Chile, alongside rising trade protectionism.

â€‹**The Takeaway:** The global energy transition is no longer just a technology race; it is a battle for control over critical minerals. As we move toward a low-carbon, AI-driven world, copper is becoming a "binding constraint" that will influence national security and industrial competitiveness.
